summary: The second of three films in the Evil Dead series is part horror, part comedy, with Ash Williams (Bruce Campbell) once again battling horrifying demons at a secluded cabin in the woods. After discovering an audiotape left by a college professor that contains voices reading from the Book of the Dead, Ash's girlfriend Linda (Denise Bixler) becomes possessed by evil spirits that are awakened by the voices on the tape. Ash soon discovers there is no escaping the woods.

Ash Williams and his girlfriend Linda find a log cabin in the woods with a voice recording from an archeologist who had recorded himself reciting ancient chants from "The Book of the Dead." As they play the recording an evil power is unleashed taking over Linda's body.
The sound quality is not the best, but it's still funny and scary.

There has never been a better visual gag in movie history than the space where a chainsaw ought to be, outlined in chalk. 

I'm sure essays can and have been written about how Evil Dead II is a clever satire of the horror flick as it had just emerged from possibly the single greatest decade for the genre in terms of popular recognition. I'm sure you could talk about the brilliant defiance of convention as Sam Raimi and co-writer Scott Spiegel played off not only their contemporaries, but the film's direct predecessor. But I don't want to talk about any of that, I want to talk about how this is the best horror-comedy of all time without needing any in-depth analysis or criticism. 

It's got gruesome gore without ever sacrificing an explicitly fun tone. There are stopmotion effects that rival anything that Harryhausen put out. It's got a guy pinning his severed hand down to the floor with a copy of Farewell to Arms. The cinematography is creative and plays directly into the demonic presence with a Looney Tunes flair. And most importantly, it's helmed by Bruce Campbell, who gives a marvelously entertaining performance as Ash, with the physical control to sell a B-movie homage with action trimmings, and facial expressions that would make Jim Carrey envious. 

Where the budget was limited, the production team used what they had to craft a film that presented itself as not only tongue-in-cheek but reverential of the classic horrors that came before. It's a film that's never not fun, even when it's soaked in blood. In fact, particularly when it's soaked in blood. (4.5/5)

Director Sam Raimi's horror comedy Evil Dead 2 (1987) is a hilarious spoof and sequel to The Evil Dead. It's very much like Raimi parodying himself with heightened shots where the direction is constantly chaotic and ever changing. Evil Dead 2 feels like Sam Raimi thought what if Ed Wood had directed The Evil Dead? Raimi's direction is so exaggerated and unhinged that I'm impressed he could come up with so many wild shots. I prefer the slightly more serious tone of The Evil Dead that also has irreverent humor and startling black comedy with Raimi's fog filled direction and innovative shots. However, Evil Dead 2 is just as great and inventive with the strangest and fiercest vision for filmmaking you can imagine. It's a funny black comedy and a fearsome horror movie when it wants to try harder.

Writers Sam Raimi and Scott Spiegel reimagine The Evil Dead, but with a bigger budget for all of the outstanding practical effects. There's bloody gore again, but with a sillier tone to keep Evil Dead 2 lighthearted most of the time. The story redoes The Evil Dead to start Evil Dead 2 with Ash possessed and insane. Every angle to shoot a film is used within Evil Dead 2. I swear this has to be one of the most creative and fun loving movies ever crafted. Sam Raimi really outdid himself with the outlandish visuals and playful ideas.

Peter Deming's cinematography looks incredible with these moody establishing wide shots of the fog covered cabin in the woods to the intense close-ups. The way the camera rushes of wind through the forest or the house like the evil spirit is chasing Ash is exhilarating every time it appears. Editor Kaye Davis uses the fastest cutting style for all of Evil Dead 2's chaotic and sharp cuts. It's incredible and mind boggling that she put together all these seemingly unrelated shots into such a coherent and pleasant horror comedy for the ages.

Bruce Campbell's magnetic charisma, sheer will power, perfect comedic timing, suave heroism, and ruthless violence as Ashley J. Williams is a pleasure to watch during Evil Dead 2. He gets to talk to himself, cut off his own hand, and rave with a mad lunacy we hope to never experience. Bruce Campbell earned his cult classic horror icon status with The Evil Dead, then charmed viewers once more with his erratic and captivating hero Ash. Campbell is beloved for his genius comedic delivery of lines like, "Groovy" with total seriousness or his visceral violence against the paranormal beings surrounding Ash and Annie.

Sarah Berry is lovely and sympathetic as Annie Knowby. She is as smart and violent as Ash, which makes Annie Knowby a fantastic final girl until the last second she's on screen. What a neat heroine Sarah Berry plays as she brings Annie to life with a cool confidence, panicked screams, vicious attacks, and intelligent occult whispering. Kassie DePaiva is captivating as the redneck girl with an attitude named Bobby Joe. She's very pretty and intriguing as she roams around the forest with her idiotic boyfriend Jake, whom Dan Hicks portrays with a zeal for intense reactions.

Art direction from Randy Bennett and Philip Duffin creates genuinely beautiful haunting moonlit nights to shine down upon Raimi's cabin in the woods. All the smoky fog builds atmosphere and suspense until the ghosts arrive en masse to terrify Ash. Elizabeth Moore's set decoration crafts a Necronomicon, book of the dead, among all the rocking chairs and woodland furniture. Everything looks dusty and ancient by design. All the ruined wood and occult ritual offerings really tie the cabin's aesthetic together nicely.

Composer Joseph LoDuca returns to score Evil Dead 2 with a similar grandeur to his symphonic orchestrations and a playful whimsy for the more comedic moments throughout the day. The fierce sound design is pretty wild with voices echoing from all over to sound more spectral when a character is being haunted by one of the ghosts. Wendy Bell and Mike Trcic's make-up wounds look wonderfully realistic as well as for all the ghostly faces throughout Evil Dead 2.

In short, Evil Dead 2 is another horror comedy masterpiece from Sam Raimi featuring some of his most daring direction ever. It's 84 brief minutes of astonishing creativity, clever wit, and fun loving playfulness. Evil Dead 2 is the perfect spooky and cute horror picture to start of Halloween season with Raimi's black comedy and grotesque horror images, then you'll see some serious chainsaw and shotgun action.

In a way Sam Raimi's horror sequel, Evil Dead II (1987) is a complete retreading of its predecessor, however it feels entirely different due to the introduction of slapstick comedy on top of the already-terrifying imagery captured from the original. It can be such an odd experience watching as you half freaked out, and half comedically amused.

Your enjoyment of Evil Dead II (1987) will determine if you like Sam Raimi as a director, as this personifies his work and him as a director, embracing the whacky side of horror. It is a film you have to embrace, and to be honest it is quite hard not to. It is bigger than its predecessor, like most sequels are, however bigger does equal better on this occasion as the gore and violence is increased as well as the range of practical and special effects.

You will not be bored watching Evil Dead II (1987), it is such a unique film, especially in the genre with how it makes you feel, and to top it all off it has a very surprising, yet intriguing ending.

Picking up right after the event of the first film, following a quick recap using new footage since the filmmakers couldn't use footage from the first film, "Evil Dead 2" the picks up with a new group of disparate characters trapped in a cabin in the woods that's under attack by the titular deadites and hope to survive the night with the lone survivor of the first film, Ash Williams. Although the film is a continuation, the story is essentially a remake of the first film, but with a bigger budget, better special effects, and better actors. The key players return for the sequel, notably director/co-writer Sam Raimi and lead actor Bruce Campbell as Ash, both much more polished at this point in their careers. Filmed seven years after the original, Raimi had directed the bigger budgeted Coen Brother scripted comedy "Crimewave" and Campbell had three films under his belt (including an appearance in "Crimewave"). Two other talented folks who joined the sequel. One was cinematographer Peter Deming, his first film, who'd go on to become Raimi's regular DP as well as going on to shoot major films such as "Twin Peaks", "Mulholland Drive", and "From Hell". The other major addition this sequel was special effects artists Howard Berger, Robert Kurtzman, and Greg Nicotero, who following their work on "Evil Dead 2" formed KNB EFX, who have done everything from "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" to "The Walking Dead" to "Reservoir Dogs" to "Misery". Beyond the film being superior to the original on a technical level, it's much funnier far more clever than the original. The dancing stop motion skeleton doing a Fred Astaire-like dance, Ash doing battle with his own severed hand, or this hilarious ending that sets things up for a wonderfully absurd sequel all make this film a very cheeky take on horror film tropes. Campbell really ups his comedy chops for this sequel, particularly when it comes to some very funny slapstick bits involving his hand "turning bad" and his mock heroic moments (which he'd go one to perfect in the third film in the series). The practical special effects and the complete absences of CGI offers old school horror fans a lot of nostalgia and retro charm as well, particularly director Sam Raimi's brother, Ted Raimi, as the Possessed Henrietta in the torn hag suit. Those are the parts everyone remembers about "Evil Dead II" but the sexy tobacco chewing Bobby Joe, played by Kassie Wesley, is a lot of fun, as is her hillbilly boyfriend Jake, played by Dan Hicks. Interestingly, Bobby Joe was inspired by Holly Hunter, who was a roommate of Raimi in the 80s along with Joel Coen and Frances McDormand. He wrote the part for Hunter, but producers overruled him and wanted someone "sexier". Overall, "Evil Dead II" is a classic. It's more openly comedic than the first film, but still manages to be scary and is a rollercoaster of fun, even if it is absolute fluff. FUN FACT! This is a funny movie, no really! Although The Evil Dead and Evil Dead II share numerous plot similarities, the tones of the features are significantly different. It is still possible to be unsettled by Evil Dead II, but far less likely than by its predecessor. It's interesting to note the way Ash changes between The Evil Dead and Evil Dead II. In the former, he's a geeky guy who ends up being a reluctant hero of sorts. In the sequel, he's a none-too-bright macho dude who's out to get the "Dead-ites". By the end of Evil Dead II, he has an impressive arsenal of weapons, including a sawed-off shotgun and a chainsaw. Evil Dead 2 is a worthy sequel to the first Evil Dead, but the tone is so different you must go in with a perspective.

Not all of the effects look good, especially compared to today's standards, but at least it was an attempt! Seriously, like, why aren't writers/directors watching this and taking notes? I know that studios are merely going by what's "hip" and because they know that if they spend a million dollars on a movie and manage to create a compelling trailer that tells you ALL of the movie's plot, then they'll make 3X what they spent by the first weekend. Sam Raimi's Evil Dead 2 is not only an insanely comedic counterpart to its more serious (and tree-rapey) predecessor, but it's a great sequel that keeps what terrified audiences six years beforehand and expands on ideas related to the Necronomicon, a book that, when read aloud, summons the undead. Here, the undead is actually a sole entity with no real flesh until the climax of the movie. The less we talk about that flesh form, the better. It is far more intimidating as this formless being we sometimes see from its own perspective, as it knocks downs trees and doors to reach its target. There's a musical chant that accompanies the being, ascending demonically as it gets closer. When it reaches a target, it torments and swallows the soul of the body, then occupies the body, becoming a zombie. The zombies themselves look like those of Dawn of the Dead, but the Evil Dead franchise is where top-speed zombies are introduced. There are jump scares and there is blood. Blood does not bleed out of bodies. It blows out like an oil well. The first time it happens -- when the hero Ash (Bruce Campbell) shoots his possessed, severed hand -- is timed so well that, despite how sick the red and black blood looks, I laugh.

The undead can possess inanimate objects too. For the first half hour, Ash is all alone in the cabin, aware of the danger that's waiting to consume him. The undead controls the piano so it plays by itself, a mirror so that Ash can rival his own reflection, and a deer head to taunt Ash when his chair collapses. Ash sometimes wakes up to "discover" he was only dreaming. Instead of determining whether his sanity is shattering or the undead is just toying with his mind, I laugh along with the antics. That deer head scene is flat-out slapstick. First, the deer head cackles at Ash, then a lamp, clock, bookcase, every object in the room. Then Ash laughs with the undead, and entertains it some more. For more evidence of slapstick, again, Ash fought his possessed, severed hand, with violence straight out of a Tom and Jerry cartoon. Once other people enter the scene, the film drags for a little while. I don't expect anyone except my hero to live. That's okay, because before the climax, Ash becomes a classic action star by attaching a chainsaw to his handless arm and exclaims some catchphrases. And when a portal is summoned to send the undead to another dimension, the film ends on a science-fiction/fantasy twist you would see in a Twilight Zone episode. I have loved this film for so long that the cons don't mean a thing to me. The fast-paced cinematography, claustrophobic setting, and psychotically silly violence are all I need for comedy-horror.

For every serious seeming bit, there's a whole 'nother scene popping out at us to remind us that the whole movie is pretty much a farce. If this is in fact Sam Raimi's initial intention, then he sure is a clever film maker.

As for the direction, I gotta say I love some of the visuals in this movie. A lot of the crappy effects in terms of the monsters and the stop motion is silly yet smile inducing, and the long single tracking shots in the beginning are actually damn impressive. There are a lot of shots, along with other choices made by Raimi that make the movie succeed in all it's cheesy, campy, glory. The music, the cheap set, the simple, played dialogue. It all works so well, to make this movie feel so cheap and stupid, yet so unique in it's own little way. After watching Evil Dead 2, I thought to myself that no one's really making movies like this anymore. Even if they are, no one's shining a light on this kind of stuff. So up to a few years ago I was a little confused by this sequel. The plot appears to show 'Ash' venturing back up to a remote cabin with another girlfriend, was this the original cabin or a completely new one? I asked myself. As things progress (very quickly) Ash discovers yet another recorder which he plays and inadvertently sets the dark demonic forces free again. It was at this point I was thinking why on earth Ash would do that? didn't he learn from his first cabin experience? and when you think about it why the hell would he go back to a remote cabin?! dude seriously!.

Twas then I found out that this sequel is actually a reboot of the first film, yet Raimi called it Evil Dead 2 as though its a continuation of the first. The plot is exactly the same as the first film because its a remake basically, a remake with better effects, more action and less build up...essentially more game time. Ash is even wearing the same outfit he had on in the first film!. So yes that is a bit confusing if you're not in the know but somehow it doesn't matter, the film is so damn fun you let it slide. Myself I think he should of avoided the 2 in the title and tried to make it follow the first but hey.

As I said there's no messing around in this film, no sooner has Ash arrived at the cabin he's released the demons and all hell is breaking loose. This is good as we know the basic outline from the first film, everybody simply wanted to see more of Ash kicking undead ass. And that is exactly what we get with much sweeter looking effects.

The effects are much the same type of thing as in the first but due to success and extra mula they are simply better. Of course by today's standards they aren't that good, a bit basic, any fresh faced kids are gonna laugh at most of it truth be told. But again its the old adage that with little money and tech you've gotta work to make your film look good. You've gotta be inventive and once again Raimi and co excel with their visuals. A nice blend of classic makeup, mask work, models, stop motion, bluescreen, miniatures, puppets etc...the full gamut of special effects to bring every creature alive in the best possible way.

Personally I loved the sequence where 'Linda's' corpse rises from the grave and then dances around in the swirling bleak mist as Ash watches in horror from the cabin. The whole scene is using classic stop motion and even though it of course looks a bit hokey the atmosphere is just so flippin eerie. It could almost be a Tim Burton moment. There is so much to enjoy here, chock full of tasty visual kookiness, the severed hand that scrambles around, the excellent possessed makeup jobs on the survivors and Campbell especially and then there's the huge demon head/face thing at the end. Corny as hell but so much fun.

Its also no secret that this sequel was taken down the horror comedy route. The first film was suppose to be an all out horror but this started down that surreal goofy route which has now become so legendary. Not for the most part though, most of the film is still very dark, some of the demonic sequences are clearly more slapstick but its still evil looking. Its only when the last female survivor crafts Ash's chainsaw onto his bloody stump along with his shoulder mounted shotgun do we finally cross over fully into the comic book/graphic novel genre. Its at this moment that Ash becomes a superhero of sorts and enters into the world of merchandise.

Does this mood swing cause any problems? no, no it doesn't, in fact it just makes the film even more awesome and gives it a whole new scope. We go from classic horror gore with Ash being the victim in all manner of slapstick tomfoolery, to action man gore and violence with the start of ice cool witty quips and full on hero posing.

It is strange how this franchise developed no doubt about that, plus the oddity of rebooting/remaking his first film virtually scene by scene and calling it a sequel. Like the first its not really scary but this time it was never meant to be scary, its a wild ride bordering on fantasy that happens to have a lot of blood and goo. Its one of those perfect 'sequels' where everything is just right, it all works...even the bits that kinda don't work, work. There are moments of great horror and moments that are almost childish in nature, you could even say its a satire of certain grotty horrors. End of the day Campbell can simply make these things work.

No excuses here, its a balls to the wall, hyper demonic blood n ooze frenzy with typically gritty low budget ferocity and absurd creations. A completely cheesy turbo charged B-movie of diabolically hellish proportions, you wanted it you got it...and its groovy baby.

Quick explanation: Starting now, I will no longer write 5,000-character reviews for movies that nobody cares about, because they tend to not get read, and it's a waste of my time. As always, recent movies that are still in theaters or came out this year will get full reviews.

If I were to sum up the Evil Dead franchise in one word, it would be "dumb." Sam Raimi, following up his cult classic (why it's considered a classic, I'll never know) gives us Evil Dead 2, easily the number-one horror movie to watch if you feel like laughing incredulously. It's billed as a horror/comedy, but there's nothing in it to make you laugh, and those who DO laugh at it miss the point that the movie doesn't seem to be intentionally funny. Which puts it on the same level as... dare I say it? The Room.

This campy, ugly, obnoxious carbon-copy of the original film is unmemorable and uninventive in every way. Its plot is virtually identical to the first movie (you'd think that Ash Williams would have learned his lesson by now and stayed away from cabins in the woods), the effects are even cheesier, and the dialogue is absolutely fucking atrocious. There are scenes where you get the feeling that Raimi just told his actors to look suddenly around the set, acting terrified. That's not even acting. That's just looking mildly frightened. By the time we get to the plot with Ash's Evil Hand, we couldn't care less.

Final Score for Evil Dead 2: 4/10 stars. I see very little redeeming value in this intrinsically, but just as with The Room, it's fun to watch it for how mind-fuckingly inept it is on every level. The acting is vomit-inducing, the story is retarded, and the special effects look better suited to Jason and the Argonauts than a sequel to a highly successful horror movie made in 1987. Seriously, this came out AFTER Star Wars. Altogether, it sucks on every level. Watch the shit out of it.

Evil Dead 2 "picks up" where the first left off, but not after retelling the first movie (this time with just Ash and his girlfriend) in the first 10 minutes. For those who don't know, Ash and his girlfriend drive up to a cabin in the woods for a fun weekend together. While there, they find a recording that when they play back summons an evil spirit. This evil spirit possesses the girl and As has to kill her. Holed up in this cabin with no way to escape, Ash fights to survive and keep his insanity until two couples show up to invite more trouble.

Sam Raimi is a brilliant director, not necessarily because he's great with actors (although to be fair he helped mold Bruce Campbell into a fairly decent one), but because of his brilliant camera and effects work. This movie looks really quite good, with camera angles that make me practically orgasm I love them so much. Raimi is the master of perpetuating mood, if that mood is right and Evil Dead 2 never looses that feeling of bat-shit insanity that Raimi intended. The lighting works extremely well too, with the woods being spooky and the film in general having that undeniably VHS era feel to it.

The effects are phenomenal, even when they suck. It makes me nostalgic for the era of practical effects (even if I was never there) because with the same budget, the cgi would have looked worse. Raimi uses stop motion at several points in the movie and stop motion at it's worse still has a creepy vibe because of how disjointed it is. CGI when it's low budget looks like shit, so even if stop-motion looks bad it's still better. The blood, makeup and various body part movements look amazing, much better then the original. There are a few effects that don't work that well and actually could have used some CG but there never going to pull you out of the movie.

Evil Dead 2 is a funny ass movie, but it still manages to pull off scares. You'll be laughing at Ash one second, cheering him on the next and fearing for him the next. It's really a roller coaster, but it does require you to understand what it's trying to do. The story is generic, the acting is mediocre, and the inconsistent tone on top of that is what's going to turn people off. However, if you go into Evil Dead expecting to not take it too seriously then the comedy will be all the funnier and the scares will be all the more unexpected.

They're back and deader than ever... so they're probably not going to be too much of a challenge this time around. Yeah, I reckon that, "Evil" adjective really does make a good bit of difference, because you're usual corpse isn't going to put up much of a fight, but if you emphasize that these are demons we're dealing with here, then things are starting to sound more hardcore. Shoot, forget the "Evil" part in the title, you could just toss in the "Dead by Dawn" subtitle for this film that they all too often don't use, because that is one cool subtitle, even if it does scream hardcore metal band almost as loudly and obnoxiously as a hardcore metal band. So yeah, this film's title is pretty hardcore, as is the film itself, but don't get too excited, people, because where "The Evil Dead" was straight brutality, this film actually gets a touch more tongue-in-cheek in order to lighten the mood or something. That's right, folks, when this sequel doesn't stay too faithful to the narrative of its predecessor that it actually revises, it betrays the predecessor's full degree of intensity with slapstick humor, so how could this possibly go, Sam Raimi. Shoot, as questionable as some of the human behavior in the first "Evil Dead" was, it may as well as have more been a comedy or something, but with this film, yeah, Raimi really doesn't make that much pretense, even though I can think of some people who would say that with this film, Raimi has earned the right to gloat a bit. I, on the other hand, respect this film, and certainly find that it works better than it could have, but am noticing some issues here.

Really, when you refer to this film as a sequel, you're more-or-less using the term rather loosely, because if nothing else is unique about this follow-up to a unique classic of sorts, it's the idea of rebooting the narrative, which is refreshed and revised entirely with this effort, - at least for the first act that removes and reintroduces characters and plot elements in a new light - yet still doesn't take full advantage of its loose interpretation of its own mythology, following more than a few of the same beats of its predecessor, or rather, "source material", and giving you a greater opportunity to see the elements in this story that aren't so refreshing. If there were clichés in the original "The Evil Dead", then most of them were obscured by originality that ultimately prevailed in bringing the predecessor about as much life as it can gain as a horror flick riddled with natural shortcomings, yet with this loose sequel/remake, in spite of some new refreshing elements, originality has gone stale enough for you to get the bitter taste of the conventionalism, which in turn allows you to sink your teeth further into other shortcomings in the story concept. Like I said, the original's story was too riddled with natural shortcoming for the final product to go all that far as enjoyable, and while this film is arguably more realized in its storytelling, with more layers and attention to substance, rather than style, it too has a certain minimalism to its subject matter that limits effectiveness, further betrayed by errors in Sam Raimi's interpretation of an improvable story concept. The film not only revises its mythology, but also revises its tone, juggling much of the same intensity that powered its predecessor, sometimes with a hint of dramatic weight, if you can believe it, but still leaving room for comedy elements that range from cleverly subtle to just about gleefully absurdist, and I commend Raimi for having the guts to try and tickle your gut while others' guts are being spilled (There are a lot of guts in this film, make no mistake), yet there are times where the film gets confused and jars between its tonal layers, whose extremes go diluted by tonal unevenness, as surely as they go tainted by pacing unevenness. Another aspect that cut down the predecessor was blanding atmospheric dryness, and while this film sustains enough liveliness to keep you far away from all-out boredom throughout its course, limp, maybe even quiet moments in atmospheric kick stiffen pacing, giving you the opportunity to notice the dragging in the plot structuring of this film, which, at a mere 84 minutes, would appear to not have any time to lose, but ultimately finds itself going bloated with excess filler that drags things along, little by little, until focus starts to fade, both within the film and perhaps even the audience. The film is fun and has a lot to commend, more so than its predecessor, but for every misstep it patches up after "The Evil Dead", it takes on a new scratch to help you in soaking up the weight limitations that ultimately drive the final product into relative underwhelmingness. Nevertheless, the film is enjoyable, (You know, if you don't mind blood and guts and whatnot) being almost as messy as it is, well, messy, (Blood and guts and whatnot) but not without its share of strengths, even in the score department.

Returning from "The Evil Dead", Joseph LoDuca turns in a score that is lacking in uniqueness, but abandons much of the blasted '70s/'80s electronic sensibilities that watered down much of the effectiveness of LoDuca's still generally effective score for the last film, replacing it with more sweep and liveliness, broken by a faithfulness to the minimalist brood that made LoDuca's score for the predecessor generally quite effective, and when it comes to the efforts of cinematographer Peter Deming, Tim Philo's replacement, filming definition is relatively sharper, as is filming style, which is more tasteful with its sparse lighting plays, as well as even more dynamic and stylish with its lively camerawork. The nifty filming style that this film explores is not only more immersive than the cinematography of the predecessor, but really compliments the dynamicity of the action sequences, not unlike Gregory Nicotero's special effects, which are a bit improvable in retrospect, but generally pretty outstanding, with a fair amount of convincingness and a great amount of conceptual liveliness, particularly when it comes to the over-the-top gore effects that may prove to be quite disturbing, but, to those willing to try and stomach the nastiness, creatively liven up the intense violence that in turn livens up a sense of consequence. Stylistically and technically, the film really steps up from its predecessor, whose style and technical value played key roles in keeping the film going as decent, so the aesthetic touch-ups, alone, bring the final product to the brink of rising above "The Evil Dead", while relatively sharper acting aspects all but solidify the sequel as superior. Now, acting material is still pretty limited, as you can imagine, but the tonal layers augment opportunities for lively performances that are, in fact, done justice, with charisma that can be found across the board, but especially within leading man Bruce Campbell, who, with this film, really defines the iconic Ash Williams character, not just with his charisma, but with a surprising amount of layered depth that sells Williams as an ordinary man who shall suffer through sorrow and terror on his path to assuming a heroic role. When material picks up, at least for Campbell, our leading man carries the film, and while that's not to say that Campbell is truly excellent, it is to say that Campbell is stronger than you'd expect him to be as the lead in a film like this, which isn't to say that there isn't some potential in this film to do justice. This film's story concept is too similar to the subject matter of both the predecessor and other horror flick's of this nature, and is therefore rich with natural limitations in meat and momentum, further watered down by inconsistencies in tone and pacing, but as surely as there was plenty of intrigue and uniqueness within "The Evil Dead", this follow-up still has much intrigue and refreshingness to spare, partly because of the film's being redefined as a comedy horror, brought to life about as much as it can be by Sam Raimi's script, - which delivers on anything from colorful, if mostly blood-red slapstick, to near-biting satire - as well as by Raimi's direction, whose effective areas in atmospheric playfulness soak up the core of the tonal layers enough to sell both tension and liveliness. Really, the film is pretty fun, and while fun isn't enough to drive the final product into a rewarding state, combined with stylistic, technical and acting strength behind refreshing and generally effective storytelling, secure the effort as quite decent, if improvable.

When it's all said and done... again, the final product is too much like its predecessor and other films of its type, as well as too uneven in tone and pacing, for you to ignore the natural shortcomings, which ultimately drive the final product into underwhelmingness, challenged more than I expected by lively score work, excellently stylish cinematography, outstanding special effects, - particularly when it comes to the creative gore - surprisingly good acting, - especially from leading man Bruce Campbell - and generally effective writing and direction that do enough justice to a generally refreshing and lively story concept for "Evil Dead II", or, if you will, "Evil Dead 2: Dead by Dawn" (I'm telling you, that is one cool subtitle), to stand as a flawed, but tense and fun comedic thriller.

As it turns out, the living dead can be real mean.  So can possessed people.  While the original "Evil Dead" in 1981 already proved this, "Evil Dead 2" is much more gory, and adds even more humor, if that's possible.  This sequel is the definition of in your face horror, but it's so gosh darn entertaining that when you're not scared, you're laughing, or vice versa.  At this point in the game, Sam Raimi was still young, but no director at the time could work with a low-budget in the way that he can.
	The film begins with a condensed recap of what happened earlier-- we find that Ash (Bruce Campbell) and his girlfriend Linda (Denise Bixler) are going to that famous dark cabin in the woods ... the Book of the Dead is discovered ... Linda becomes possessed ... and then Ash is forced to kill her.  
	From then on, "Evil Dead 2" stands alone.  The film jumps to an airport, where we meet Annie (Sarah Berry), the daughter of the people that own the cabin (and the ones responsible for awakening the dead), and her professor boyfriend Ed (Richard Domeier).  The twosome plan on visiting Annie's parents, but upon a rival they find that the bridge has mysteriously been destroyed.  They enlist the help of two rednecks, Jake (Dan Hicks) and Bobby Joe (Kassie DePaiva) to guide them along the alternate trail to the came.
	When they show up, Ash has battled a slew of evil spirits, and is a complete mess.  Annie, seeing the cabin all shook up and bloody, believes that Ash killed her parents-- but she's mistaken.
	"Evil Dead 2" puts shame to all of the low-budget horror flicks that plagued the 1980s.  With only three million, Raimi manages to use his restraints in the most endearing of ways, even if it's obvious stop-motion special effects, or loopy camera tricks that are simple yet effective.  Whether it be spooky fog floating through the forest or wind that sounds like it came out of a Scooby Doo episode, "Evil Dead 2" still manages to be scary.
	Oddly enough, with all the blood, gore, and the monstrous faces of the crazed Deadites, there is plenty of room for slapstick comedy.  One would expect it to have the dark humor of a "Scream" movie, but on the contrary, Raimi sets certain scenes that are truly meant to be funny.  The one that truly sticks out is when poor Ash, covered with grime and scared to death, discovered his hand has been possessed.  You can only imagine how he reacts.
	As you watch the film though, don't expect any of the brilliance of "Psycho," because that's in a whole different league.  The acting is mediocre (except for the wonderful Campbell ... and you can't forget Berry's harmonious scream), the one-liners are cheesy, and the film would rather be silly than serious.  But nevertheless, "Evil Dead 2" is so much fun that it deserves repeated viewings.  This is one of the few cult films where I can truly see why its followers are so supportive.

I wouldn't say its as good as the original but it certainly is a very good entry in the Evil Dead trilogy. Very well done, very creative camera angles, chilling atmosphere, and deeper character development. Things really start to pick up here, there's even a scene where we have the camera moving through the cabin of what we assume is a point of view shot because we never actually see what it is that is moving through the cabin chasing Ash. Again Bruce Campbell returns playing the role of Ash and what we can assume completely ignores the very first Evil Dead and starts completely over from the side of Ash in a completely different approach where as it is just him and his girlfriend going up to a cabin. Instead of a bunch of killer people, it centers more on Ash and his transition from creature to human, it goes more along the lines of inner turmoil and personal struggle as Ash tries to hang on to his sanity. There are a few scenes where he absolutely loses it and even we start to wonder what is really happening or is it all in his head. His character even alternates between good and evil so we are never exactly sure what could possibly happen next. Its a fine mix of comedy and horror in this film, but towards the end of the movie Ash goes completely bad ass and gains a chainsaw for a hand in what may be one of the most epic things ever, a chainsaw for a hand and a sawed off shotgun. Its a very fine mix of horror, action, and comedy that is definitely worth the watch. I definitely recommend this one to any horror fan, great sequel indeed.
